description: From Middle English *oversteppen, from Old English ofersteppan, from Proto-Germanic *uberstapjaną (“to step over; overstep”), equivalent to over- +‎ step. Cognate with Dutch overstappen, German Low German överstappen, German überstapfen, überstepfen.

entries.meaning: A gait in which the hind foot touches ground in front of where the front foot touches the ground.
A movement in which one oversteps.

verbs.description: overstep (third-person singular simple present oversteps, present participle overstepping, simple past and past participle overstepped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To go too far beyond (a limit); especially, to cross boundaries or exceed norms or conventions.
examples: That color scheme really oversteps the bounds of good taste.

entries.meaning: To take a step in which the foot touches ground too far forward.
To move with a gait such that the hind foot touches the ground forward of the point where the front foot touches the ground.
